newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Dutch minister derides "miraculous" EU forecasts.
newsitem.headline: Dutch minister derides "miraculous" EU forecasts.

text.p: Dutch Finance Minister Gerrit Zalm expressed scepticism on Wednesday about EU forecasts which showed 13 of the 15 EU states on track to meet the three percent deficit-to-GDP ratio needed to join economic and monetary union.
"The Commission has published figures which in a miraculous manner come out at precisely three (percent) for a large number of countries," Zalm said in a radio interview.
Forecasts for France, Germany, Spain and Portugal showed the Commission expected those four countries to qualify for EMU with 1997 deficits of exactly 3.0 percent of gross domestic product.
"It would be a real fluke if that proved to be the actual outcome, so we are going to have to wait for the results which we'll be able to see in early 1998," Zalm said.
Zalm said the European Commission had faced great political pressure in preparing the figures.
"You risk your life, so to speak, if you put a country above three percent when the country itself thinks it should be below three percent," he said.
Zalm, who previously headed the Dutch government's economic forecasting agency, said the decision on who qualifed for EMU would be based on actual results not forecasts.
"Forecasts don't really mean a lot. I know that from experience," he said.
